channel.title: Half-Life 3 Ideas
channel.description:
Yes I know what you are all thinking... "Oh, stupid thread." But no, I'm posting this thread because I want to see what hardcore Half-Life and VALVE fans think should be in Half-Life 3. No I do not work for VALVE in any shape or form or way.
Anyways, I think the second half will be in the Wasteland.

item.title: Half-Life 3 Ideas
item.dc:creator: BahamutBBob
item.description:
Typically in modern zombie stories, zombies are rotting corpses that happen to be able to move.

Not always (World War Z, Resident Evil movies as two examples where decomposition stops after a certain point) but most of the time.

That would explain some of their frailty, anyway.

item.title: Half-Life 3 Ideas
item.dc:creator: Kaweebo
item.description:
xalener:

Yes and just recently yes.

But yeah, I want l4d2 style gibs in HL3. Maybe a not as overstated. A shotgun in HL doesn’t seem like it’d do the damage a shotgun in l4d2 does.

Yes, but they seem to fall apart a little TOO easily. I’m not saying I’ve seen a person get shot point blank with a shotgun before, and I know it’d do horrific damage, but the zombies gib and fall apart sorta’ve like their skin is made of paper. In fact in the L4D wiki they addressed this by making up theories as to why that is, such as the infection weakening their body. I’m not really saying this just from the shotgun but such as with the axe. I doubt hitting someone with an axe would slice through them as seemingly effortlessly as it does in L4D2. So, I’d like to see more realistic gibs and damage but not really to that extreme.

item.title: Half-Life 3 Ideas
item.dc:creator: Mented
item.description:
My perfect NPC would not only have body parts able to be blown off, but also go into certain animations depending on where they are hit, until they are actually dead, in which case they become ragdolls.

That is unless they have explosions killing them, in which case have them torn apart/blown apart in a more realistic version of HL1 style gibbing.

It isn’t necessary, and I’m yet to find a game that does it all, but it’d be kewl no doubt.

item.title: Half-Life 3 Ideas
item.dc:creator: Ranzua
item.description:
Maxey:

HL3 needs smarter humanoid enemies that do more than just shoot at me, take cover and occasionally try to flank me or flush me out with grenades. In fact, something analogous to the Assassin from HL1 needs to make a return but which applies more clever tactics to try to get me.

An improved version of the animation techniques used for the zombies in the L4D games. The animation for the combine soldiers in HL2 was good enough for 2004, but technology has moved on and if HL3 pretends to compete directly with the latest in gaming, they at least need to have the combine soldiers to move around as realistically as the L4D zombies, including the way they react to being hit.

Bigger puzzles that may take a whole level to complete, interspersed with combat sequences.

Keep the game progression linear but make the levels a bit more open and with more paths to take.

Related to the idea above, add stealth elements. Take some cues from Deus Ex and add ways for players to be able sneak around enemies in certain levels. If you can sneak on an enemy from behind, a whack from the crowbar should be a one hit kill.

I’m sure they can do that, they just need to do some dev work better, I saw the NPCs in Postal 3 ( which runs on source) we’re able to take cover and even shoot at you from behind cover, something like that might add some cool depth of strategy to the game

item.title: Half-Life 3 Ideas
item.dc:creator: ChancyWancy
item.description:
Unique death animations for each enemy would also be cool. Like if I shoot a Combine Soldier in the stomach with a crossbow dart, let him be aware of it for a moment before the ragdoll physics kick in. For example: if there’s not a wall behind him, when he’s hit by the bolt and laying on his back he should attempt to rise up as if to stare at the wound and then fall back down with his dying breath. Similarly, if there’s a wall behind him, maybe he stays conscious for awhile still pinned to the wall.

This idea is inspired by RAGE’s way of combat where depending on where you shoot an enemy, they recognize the wound yet still try and attack you. In that game, you can throw a wingstick (bladed boomerang-like weapon) and it can land in the enemies neck and stay, or sometimes go all the way through and cut it off.
